p: A contrasting “amplification effect” is expected when between-species disease transmission increases with host diversity [ 4]. For example, infection with tick-borne Anaplasma, a pathogen that causes rickettsial disease, varied among small mammal species and vegetation types, but overall was higher in habitats where mammalian diversity was higher [ 6]. Thus, the nuances of the biological system affect the predicted trajectory of disease transmission in ecological communities.
